choices.text: βhCG levels > 100,000
Plateau in βhCG levels
Theca lutein cyst > 6 cm
Younger maternal age

questions.text: All are risk factors for progression of Hydatidiform mole to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Younger maternal age

 

Older maternal age is a risk factor for progress to GTN

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Risk Factors for progress to GTN

 

  1. Complete mole (15%) > Partial mole (5%)

  2. Older Maternal Age

  3. βhCG levels > 100,000

  4. Uterine size large for gestational age

  5. Theca lutein cysts > 6 cm

  6. Slow decline in βhCG levels

 

Ref: page no 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Mifepristone + Misoprostol
Conservative management
Suction & Evacuation
Hysterotomy

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of 3 months pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is palpable. An ultrasound shows the following picture. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Suction & Evacuation

  • This image shows the typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’
  • This seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • The treatment of a molar pregnancy is suction evacuation followed by beta hCG surveillance

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for 1st trimester MTPs or missed abortions but not for molar pregnancy
  • Option B: Conservative management will not help as the molar tissue has to be evacuated
  • Option D: Hysterotomy is NOT indicated for a molar pregnancy, even for larger gestational ages, a suction evacuation is done

Educational Objective: 

Treatment of a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation followed by beta hCG surveilance

 

Ref: Page no. 391, 392 William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Partial mole
Complete mole
Down syndrome
Turner Syndrome

questions.text: Paternal chromosomal duplication is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Complete mole

Paternal chromosomal duplication is seen in COMPLETE mole

Educational Objective: 

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOID
    • 2 sperm fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component present
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ovum and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis.
  • 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum.
  • 46 XX or 46 XY
  • Only paternal component
  • No maternal component

 

Ref: Page no 389, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 6 weeks
7 weeks
8 weeks
9 weeks

questions.text: During post evacuation surveillance following evacuation of a complete mole, the median time for resolution of serum βhCG values is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 9 weeks

The median time for resolution of serum βhCG values is

  • 7 weeks for partial mole
  • 9 weeks for complete mole

 

Ref: page no 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 1-5%
5-10%
10-15%
15-20%

questions.text: A 23y woman has a suction evacuation for molar pregnancy. The HPE is reported as a partial mole. You counsel her that her risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-5%

Educational Objective: 

  • Risk of progress of complete mole to GTN: 15-20 %
  • Risk of progress of partial mole to GTN: 1-5%

 

Ref: Page 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Ring of Pearls appearance
Rokitansky nodule
Snowstorm appearance
Waterlily sign

questions.text: Identify the ultrasound finding:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Snowstorm appearance

  • The mass is composed of numerous anechoic cystic spaces of different sizes and shapes, but without a fetus or amniotic sac.
  • The appearance is often described as a “snowstorm” .
  • Application of color Doppler displays marked surrounding myometrial vascularity. However, absent internal flow reflects the avascular villi of complete moles.

Educational Objective: 

This image shows the typical snowstorm appearance seen on ultrasound in complete molar pregnancy

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics, 26 edition, chapter 13.

choices.text: Fluid overload
Metastatic disease suggestive of GTN
Thyroid storm
Trophoblastic embolization

questions.text: A woman with molar pregnancy is undergoing suction evacuation. Suddenly she develops breathing difficulty, tachypnoea and falls in saturation. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Trophoblastic embolization

Trophoblastic Embolization

Respiratory distress rarely occurs in patients with a complete mole. It is usually diagnosed in patients with excessive uterine size and markedly elevated hG levels. These patients may have chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia and may experience severe respiratory distress during and after molar evacuation. Auscultation of the chest usually reveals diffuse rays, and chest radiographic evaluation may show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Respiratory distress usually resolves within 72 hours with cardiopulmonary support. In some circumstances, patients may require mechanical ventilation

 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16th edition. 2767

choices.text: Curette
Karman cannula
Manual vacuum aspiration syringe
Pipelle suction curette

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Karman cannula

Suction curettage Within a few minutes of commencing suction curettage, the uterine size may decrease dramatically, and the bleeding will be well controlled. The use of a 12-mm cannula is strongly advised to facilitate evacuation. If the uterus is larger than 14 weeks of gestation, one hand should be placed on top of the fundus, and the uterus should be massaged to stimulate uterine contraction and reduce the risk of perforation.

Sharp curettage is done when suction evacuation is believed to be complete, gentle sharp curettage is performed to remove any residual molar tissue.

 

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2770

choices.text: Choriocarcinoma
Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT)
Molar pregnancy
Placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT)

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia includes all Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Molar pregnancy

 

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a group of uncommon conditions associated with pregnancy. Histologically, it includes the premalignant partial hydatidiform mole (PHM) and complete hydatidiform mole (CHM), as well as the malignant invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT). The last three malignant forms can arise after any type of pregnancy and all are collectively known as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). The GTD spectrum has recently been expanded to also include atypical placental site nodule (APSN) as 10%–15% may coexist with or develop into PSTT/ETT

 

 

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: 4
5
6
7

questions.text: Mean pH of vagina during pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 4

 

Explanation:

 

Vagina

 

  • Acidic pH (3.5 – 6): due to conversion of glycogen into lactic acid by the Lactobacillus acidophilus (due to high estrogen level)

 

Educational Objective:
 

 

Ref: Page no 52, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Increase in ventricular stroke volume
Increase in systemic vascular resistance
Cardiac output is higher in lateral recumbent than supine position
Increase in heart rate

questions.text: All are true about hemodynamic changes in pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Increase in systemic vascular resistance

 

Explanation:

 

  • Systemic vascular resistance is reduced in pregnancy thereby causing a fall in BP

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Increase in ventricular stroke volume: The stroke volume is increased in pregnancy
  • Option C: Cardiac output is higher in lateral recumbent than supine position: This is because in supine position there is compression of the aorta and the IVC
  • Option D: Increase in heart rate: The heart rate increases in pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Systemic vascular resistance is reduced in pregnancy thereby causing a fall in BP

 

Ref: Page 58, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Carrier protein for estrogen and progesterone
Helps in maintenance of placenta
Immunosuppression against fetal antigens
Maintains colloid osmotic pressure in maternal blood

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the function of pregnancy associated plasma protein A (PAPP-A)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Immunosuppression against fetal antigens

 

  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy.
  • This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis.
  • Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term.
  • Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes (intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth).

 

Maternal serum level of PAPP-A:

 

  • Decreased PAPP-A indicate increased risk of trisomy 21 and trisomy 18
  • First trimester low PAPP-A (< 0.4 MoM) associated with an increased frequency of adverse obstetrical outcomes like Fetal growth restriction, pre-eclampsia, abruption, and intrauterine death

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pregnancy-associated plasma protein-A (PAPP-A) largest of the pregnancy associated proteins is produced by both the embryo and the placenta (syncytio-cytotrophoblasts) during pregnancy.
  • This protein is thought to have several different functions, including preventing recognition of the fetus by the maternal immune system, matrix mineralization and angiogenesis.
  • Levels of PAPP-A rise from first detection in the first trimester until term.
  • Maternal serum concentrations are related to subsequent fetal growth and this relationship has suggested that it can be used as a diagnostic test for adverse pregnancy outcomes (intrauterine growth restriction, premature birth, preeclampsia, and stillbirth).

 

Ref: Page no 863, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Endometriosis
History of salpingitis
Previous ectopic pregnancy
Previous cesarean

questions.text: All are risk factors for tubal ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Previous cesarean

 

Explanation:

 

  • Previous cesarean section is NOT a risk factor for tubal ectopic pregnancy

 

Let’s Discuss all the other options:

 

  • Option A: Endometriosis affects tubal motility due to adhesions and thus increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy
  • Option B: Salpingitis is inflammation of the fallopian tube. A past h/o salpingitis may have led to tubal damage and hence affect tubal motility thereby leading to a higher risk of tubal ectopic
  • Option C: Previous h/o ectopic is also a risk factor for a repeat tubal ectopic as it means there is an underlying pathology

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risk Factors of ectopic pregnancy

 

  • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): As per Williams Obstetrics 25th edition (page 371): HIGHEST RISK
  • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
  • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
  • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
  • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
  • Congenital tubal anomalies
  • Infertility (artificial Reproductive techniques like IVF)
    • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
  • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)
    • Intra uterine devices
    • Progesterone only pill

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Dilatation and evacuation
Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy
Urgent ultrasound
Urgent serum βhCG

questions.text: A 24y lady presented to the emergency with generalized pain and spotting PV. Her LMP was 2 months back and she has a history of irregular cycles. On examination, she is pale, her PR is 110/ min, BP is 80/60 mmHg. There is guarding and rigidity on abdominal examination and a vaginal exam reveals cervical motion tenderness. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis.
  • Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Dilatation and evacuation: This is not done in an ectopic pregnancy
  • Option C: Doing an ultrasound (no matter how urgently in a patient with shock) will cause a delay and worsen patient prognosis
  • Option D: Beta hCG (even urgent will take a few hours) is not indicated in a ruptured ectopic. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic

 

Educational Objective:

 

D/d of bleeding in the 1st trimester

 

  1. Implantation bleeding (Placental Sign)
  2. Abortion (threatened, inevitable, incomplete, complete, missed)
  3. Ectopic Pregnancy
  4. Molar pregnancy
  • Classic triad of symptoms I.e., pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is seen in an ectopic pregnancy.
  • In this scenario there is pain and bleeding with a positive pregnancy test and on examination there is pallor, shock and intraperitoneal bleed which points to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.
  • Next best management option is immediate surgical management and salpingectomy

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Pain, bleeding, pallor
Pain, delayed menstruation, pallor
Bleeding, pain, delayed menstruation
Pallor, pain, delayed menstruation

questions.text: The classic triad of clinical features in an ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Bleeding, pain, delayed menstruation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Clinical Features of an ectopic pregnancy vary but is typically characterized by the classic triad of
    1. Delayed menstruation
    2. Abdominal pain
    3. Vaginal Bleeding

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Clinical Features of an ectopic pregnancy vary but is typically characterized by the classic triad of
    • Delayed menstruation
    • Abdominal pain
    • Vaginal Bleeding
  • Other symptoms may include:
    • Passage of a decidual cast
    • Severe hemoperitoneum: diaphragmatic irritation – shoulder pain
    • Pallor, Shock – uterine rupture
    • Abdominal tenderness
    • Bimanual exam: cervical motion tenderness
    • Tender boggy mass in the post fornix (collected blood)
    • Cullen’s sign: Periumbilical bluish discoloration due to intraperitoneal bleeding

choices.text: Bagel sign
Blob sign
Lemon sign
Tubal ring

questions.text: All are ultrasound signs of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lemon sign

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options:

 

  • Option A: Bagel sign: This is a ‘bagel’ or doughnut shaped structure seen in the adnexa on ultrasound typical of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Option B: Blob sign: This is also a sign seen in ectopic pregnancy wherein a Heteroechoic structure is seen in the adnexal region
  • Option C: Lemon sign: This is a sign seen in spina bifida which shows pinching of the calvarium
  • Option D: Tubal ring: This is a ring like structure on ultrasound seen in ectopic pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Suspected unruptured ectopic pregnancy: Trans-vaginal Sonography (TVS) will reveal

 

  • An absent intra-uterine pregnancy
  • The presence of a pseudo-sac in the uterine cavity
  • The presence of an adnexal mass separate from the ovary
    • Hyperechoic ring surrounding an anechoic sac- seen in 20% (bagel sign/tubal ring sign)
    • Inhomogeneous mass – 60% (blob sign)
    • Obvious gestational sac with a fetal pole – 13%
  • On color doppler: “Ring of fire” seen. (D/d – Corpus luteal cyst)

 

Ref: page no 375, William Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 500 IU/L
1500 IU/L
2500 IU/L
3500 IU/L

questions.text: The value of βhCG above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be seen is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 1500 IU/L

 

Explanation:

 

Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,

 

  • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
  • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: A failing intrauterine pregnancy
A Hydatiform mole
A recent complete abortion
An ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A 20y G2A1 presents at 6 weeks pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On TVS, no gestational sac is visualized. Her serum βhCG is 2000 IU/L. Which is NOT a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A Hydatiform mole

 

Explanation:

 

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS
  • So, if serum βhCG levels are more than the discriminatory zone and still an intrauterine gestational sac is not seen on ultrasound, it is called a pregnancy of undetermined location & the following should be suspected:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Failing intrauterine pregnancy
    • Recent complete abortion
    • Early multifetal pregnancy

 

Other option

 

  • In molar pregnancy, the βhCG levels are very high (usually > 100,000)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • If serum βhCG levels are more than the discriminatory zone and still an intrauterine gestational sac is not seen on ultrasound, it is called a pregnancy of undetermined location & the following should be suspected:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Failing intrauterine pregnancy
    • Recent complete abortion
    • Early multifetal pregnancy

 

Ref: page no 374, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Expectant management
Single dose inj Methotrexate
Laparoscopic salpingostomy
Laparoscopic salpingectomy

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents to the gyn OPD with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. She has no symptoms and is hemodynamically stable. Her βhCG is 600 IU/L. The ultrasound shows a gestational sac measuring 20 mm in the right adnexa with no yolk sac or embryo seen. Which of these is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Expectant management

 

Explanation:

 

This patient fulfills all the criteria for Expectant management, i.e. no active intervention needs to be done. Just following up with weekly beta hCG levels (it should decrease every week)

 

Let’s discuss the other options

 

  • Option B: Single dose inj Methotrexate: This is medical management and is indicated in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:
  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)
  • Option C and D: Laparoscopic salpingostomy/ salpingectomy: Surgical management in an unruptured ectopic is indicated in a woman with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy with
  1. Significant pain OR
  2. Gestational sac size > 3.5 cm OR
  3. Visible cardiac activity on ultrasound OR
  4. Hemodynamically unstable patient OR
  5. Beta hCG > 5000 IU/L
  • The choice between salpingotomy or salpingectomy is made based on the following: Salpingectomy (Removing the whole tube) is preferred In women whose family is complete, if the tube is grossly distorted anatomically, if the ectopic has happened at the sire of a previous ectopic or at the site of a previous tubal ligation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Expectant Management

 

  • Only for clinically stable asymptomatic women with an ultrasound diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy with the following features
  1. Clinically stable with No pain AND
  2. Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L AND
  3. Tubal ectopic < 35mm with no visible heartbeat AND
  4. Able to return for follow up
  • Repeat βhCG levels on days 2, 4 and 7 after the original test
  • If βhCG levels drop ≥ 15% from the previous values, then repeat weekly till a negative result
  • If values fall < 15%, stay the same or rise from the previous value, review the condition and consider shifting to medical/ surgical management

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

choices.text: Methotrexate
Mifepristone
Misoprostol
Potassium chloride

questions.text: The drug of choice for medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

 

Explanation:

 

  • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate.
  • MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose
  • Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.

 

Other options:

 

  • Option B: Mifepristone: This is also known as RU486 and is a selective progesterone receptor modulator with strong anti-progestogenic action. It is commonly used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy along with misoprostol in 1st and 2nd trimester.
  • Option C: Misoprostol: This is PGE1 and is a uterotonic. It induces uterine contractions and is therefore used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy, induction of labor and prophylaxis and management of atonic PPH.
  • Option D: KCl: Ultrasound guided Intracardiac injection of Kcl is used in selective fetal termination in multifetal pregnancy reduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate.
  • MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose
  • Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.
  • 2 regimes:

 

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Expectant
Medical
Surgical
Medical + Surgical

questions.text: The preferred treatment in heterotopic pregnancy with a viable intra-uterine pregnancy with an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Surgical

 

Explanation:

 

  • Incidence of heterotopic pregnancy: increasing due to ART
  • Treatment of choice: Surgical i.e. laparoscopic salpingectomy/ salpingostomy
  • Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Expectant management is not preferred in a heterotopic pregnancy
  • Option B: Medical management: Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also
  • Option D: Medical + Surgical: There is no role of both medical and surgical management in a heterotopic pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A heterotopic pregnancy is an intra uterine pregnancy with an ectopic pregnancy
  • Incidence of heterotopic pregnancy: increasing due to ART
  • Treatment of choice: Surgical i.e. laparoscopic salpingectomy/ salpingostomy
  • Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also

 

Ref: page no 142, Textbook of Obstetrics JB Sharma

choices.text: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign
Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign.
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.text: A 30-year lady presented to the gyn OPD with complaints of mild abdominal pain and spotting. She gives a history of delayed menses by about 7 days. Her UPT is faintly positive. An ultrasound with color doppler reveals the following image. What is the diagnosis and what is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

 

Explanation:

 

  • The patient’s history is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy (classic triad of pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is there)
  • The image shows the classical “ring of fire” sign which is peri-trophoblastic vascularity.
  • Other options:
    • Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign: A corpus luteal cyst can present with vascularity around it on Doppler and appear like the ing of fire, not circle of fire
    • Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign: This could be a close differential to the question given but, in the question, the classic triad of ectopic is also mentioned which will not be seen in a corpus luteal cyst
    • Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign: The name of the sign is “Ring of fire”

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

  • The above image showing vascularity around a sac like structure is called the ring of fire sign and is seen in unruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

Ref: page no 376, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Continue with the scheduled immunization schedule.
Delay the completion of immunization till after delivery
Terminate the pregnancy and continue the immunization
Delay the immunization till after 20 weeks as organogenesis will be complete by then.

questions.text: A 24-year woman in her 1st antenatal checkup reveals to her Doctor that she had taken the 1st dose of Hepatitis B immunization prior to conception. She now asks if she should continue with the immunization schedule or not. What is the correct response?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Continue with the scheduled immunization schedule

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hepatitis B vaccination is safe in pregnancy and the immunization schedule can be continued if the patient becomes pregnant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hepatitis B immunization in pregnancy: Indicated in:

 

  • Those women completing their immunization schedule which was started pre conception
  • High risk groups – Household contacts, partners are positive, multiple sexual partners, chronic liver disease, HIV +ve
  • Dose: 0.5-1 ml IM at 0, 1, 6 months (dose depends upon the brand of hepatitis vaccine)

 

Ref: Page No 172 William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Inj Td: 1st dose: early in pregnancy, 2nd dose: After 4 weeks; booster:  if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years
Inj TT 1st dose early in pregnancy, 2nd dose after 4 weeks and booster if received 2 TT doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years
Inj Tdap 1st dose in the 2nd trimester and 2nd dose in the 3rd trimester
Inj TT or Td 1st dose in early pregnancy and 2nd dose after 4 weeks.

questions.text: What is the preferred schedule of immunization in pregnancy regarding tetanus as per the ministry of health and family welfare?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inj Td: 1st dose: early in pregnancy, 2nd dose: After 4 weeks; booster:  if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years

 

Explanation:

 

Vaccines given in pregnancy as per Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

 

  • TT, Td or Tdap
    • Td has replaced TT (as per MOHFW)
    • 1st dose: early in pregnancy
    • 2nd dose: After 4 weeks
    • Booster:  if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years

 

**As per ACOG Committee Guidelines 2017, Tdap: One dose of Td replaced with Tdap preferably given between 27-36 weeks of gestation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vaccines given in pregnancy as per Ministry of Health and Family Welfare

 

  • TT, Td or Tdap
    • Td has replaced TT (as per MOHFW)
    • 1st dose: early in pregnancy
    • 2nd dose: After 4 weeks
    • Booster:  if received 2 Td doses in a pregnancy within the last 3 years

 

  • **As per ACOG Committee Guidelines 2017, Tdap: One dose of Td replaced with Tdap preferably given between 27-36 weeks of gestation

 

Ref: https://www.fogsi.org/wp-content/uploads/2015/11/vaccination_women.pdf

choices.text: Give the Rubella vaccine.
Advise her not to conceive for the next 3 months.
Advise her not to conceive for the next 1 month.
Tell her she can safely conceive.

questions.text: A 32-year woman who is planning to conceive visits her doctor for a pre conceptional visit. The Doctor asks her if she has been immunized against Rubella. She is not sure so she is advised to get a IgG rubella done which is positive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tell her she can safely conceive

 

Explanation:

 

  • A positive IgG rubella means that she is immunized against rubella
  • She does not require any vaccination and can safely plan conception
  • If she was IgG rubella negative, then she is susceptible to rubella in pregnancy and should be advised rubella vaccination
  • As it is a live vaccine, she should not conceive for at least 1 month following vaccination

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A positive IgG rubella indicates the patient is immune and does not require pre-conceptional rubella vaccination

 

Ref: Page no 499, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Mumps, Measles, and Rubella (MMR) vaccine
Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine
Human papillomavirus (HPV) vaccine
All the above

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is scheduled for her prenatal visit. She inquires about vaccines recommended during pregnancy. Which vaccine is generally considered safe and recommended for pregnant women to protect both the mother and the newborn?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tetanus, diphtheria, and acellular pertussis (Tdap) vaccine

 

Explanation:

 

  • The Tdap vaccine is generally considered safe and recommended for pregnant women, typically between 27-36 weeks of gestation. This vaccine helps protect the mother from tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis (whooping cough), and it also provides passive immunity to the newborn, as pertussis can be severe in infants.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option C: The HPV vaccine is not typically given during pregnancy. It is usually recommended for females before becoming pregnant to prevent HPV infection, which can lead to cervical cancer. If a woman becomes pregnant during the HPV vaccination series, it is generally recommended to complete the series after pregnancy, as there is limited data on its use during pregnancy.
  • Option A: The MMR vaccine is not typically recommended during pregnancy because it is a live attenuated vaccine, meaning it contains weakened forms of the viruses. Live vaccines are generally contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential risks to the developing fetus.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • Tdap is safe in pregnancy; given between 27-36 weeks; can replace the 2nd dose of Td; provides immunity to mother and newborn against tetanus, diphtheria, and pertussis.

 

 Ref: Page no 172, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Administer the hepatitis B vaccine during pregnancy.
Delay hepatitis B vaccination until after delivery.
Hepatitis B vaccination is not necessary for pregnant healthcare workers.
Recommend hepatitis B vaccination after assessing the patient's risk factors.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman, who is a healthcare worker, asks about receiving the hepatitis B vaccine during pregnancy. What is the most appropriate recommendation regarding hepatitis B vaccination for pregnant healthcare workers?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recommend hepatitis B vaccination after assessing the patient's risk factors.

 

Explanation:

 

  • Hepatitis B vaccination is recommended for pregnant healthcare workers, but the timing should be individualized. Pregnant healthcare workers should be assessed for their risk of exposure to hepatitis B and, if indicated, should receive the vaccine after careful consideration of the potential benefits and risks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hepatitis B vaccine is safe in pregnancy and is recommended to high risk groups

 

Ref: Page no 172, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Intra-decidual sign is negative
It is eccentric in position
Peripheral vascularity is seen
Yolk sac is seen at 5.5 weeks

questions.text: All are features of a true sac except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intra-decidual sign is negative

 

Explanation:

 

  • Intra-decidual sign is seen in a true sac

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: A true sac is eccentric in position
  • Option C: Peripheral vascularity is seen in a true gestational sac
  • Option D: Yolk sac is seen at 5.5 weeks in a TVS

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page No 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Early intra-uterine pregnancy
Intra-uterine pseudo gestational sac
Tubal ectopic pregnancy
Molar pregnancy

questions.text: Double Decidual Sac sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Early Intra – uterine pregnancy

 

Explanation:

 

Double decidual sac sign is seen in an intra-uterine pregnancy.

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B: An intra-uterine pseudo sac is seen usually in an ectopic pregnancy, It is fluid collection in the uterus
  • Option C: Tubal ectopic pregnancy: in this a double decidual sac sign wont be seen. USG signs of a tubal pregnancy include bagel sign, blob sign and ring of fire sign
  • Option D: In Molar pregnancy, the characteristic sign seen is the snowstorm appearance

 

Educational Objective:

 

Double Decidual sac sign:

 

  • Is a useful feature on early pregnancy ultrasound to confirm an early intrauterine pregnancy (IUP) 
  • Especially useful when the yolk sac or embryo is still not visualized.
  • It consists of the decidua parietalis (lining the uterine cavity) and decidua capsularis (lining the gestational sac)
  • It is seen as two concentric rings surrounding an anechoic gestational sac.
  • Where the two adhere is the decidua basalis, and is the site of future placental formation.

 

 

Another sign of an intra-uterine pregnancy is the intra-decidual sign.

 

Ref: Page no 159, William’s Obstetrics

choices.text: Anterior Placenta Previa
Posterior Placenta Previa
Ant low lying placenta previa
Posterior low lying placenta previa

questions.text: Identify the condition as shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior Placenta Previa 

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is an Obstetric ultrasound showing the lower uterine segment with the bladder anteriorly. The cervix is seen and the placenta is seen posteriorly (as it is opposite to the bladder). It is seen to partially cover the os. So, this is Post placenta previa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Placenta previa is classified as follows: (obsolete)

 

 

Type 1 ---Mild degree ----- Type 2     Type 3--- Major degree ----- Type 4

 

Type 1: Low lying:  implantation in lower uterine segment but not touching the os.

 

Type 2: Marginal: placenta is at the edge of the os but not covering it

 

Type 3: Partial Placenta Previa: Placenta partially covering the internal os.

 

Type 4: Complete Placenta Previa: Placenta completely covering the internal os.

 

  • Placenta previa can also be classified on USG as (Newer system)
    • True placenta previa : the placenta covers the internal os either partially or completely
    • Low lying placenta:  placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment such that the edge does not reach the os  but remains  outside a 2 cm wide  perimeter around the os.

 

Ref: Page 774, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: ≥ 20 mm
≥ 25 mm
≥ 30 mm
≥ 35 mm

questions.text: A 34-year primi presents at 8 weeks pregnancy, The ultrasound shows an anembryonic pregnancy. An anembryonic pregnancy is when, on ultrasound, the embryo is not seen at a Mean Sac Diameter (MSD) of:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. ≥ 25mm

 

Explanation:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a MSD ≥ 25 mm – anembryonic pregnancy
  • Absence of Cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm – non-viable pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Absence of an embryo at a MSD ≥ 25 mm – anembryonic pregnancy
  • Absence of Cardiac activity at a CRL ≥ 7 mm – non-viable pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Biparietal diameter
Crown – Rump length
Head circumference
Femur length

questions.text: The best measurement for estimating gestational age on ultrasound is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Crown-Rump Length

 

Explanation

 

  • CRL: This is the Crown-Rump Length and is the most accurate method to establish and confirm the gestational age

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Biparietal diameter (BPD): The BPD is a measurement of the fetus done after 14 weeks. It is the most accurate estimation of gestational age after 14 weeks.
  • Option C: Head circumference: The HC is a measurement done after 14 weeks
  • Option D: Femur length is also a fetal biometric measurement done after 14 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

About Crown Rump Length (CRL)

 

  • Most accurate method to establish/ confirm gestational age
  • It is measured in the mid – sagittal plane
  • Embryo in neutral position
  • Till 13 weeks: accuracy of 5 – 7 days
  • In the 2nd trimester the best parameter to estimate gestational age in:  BPD
  • If dolichocephaly/ brachycephaly; HC better
  • Abdominal Circumference (AC): greatest variation

 

Ref: Page no 159, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: To assess for neural tube defects
To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy
To estimate amniotic fluid volume
To check for placental abnormalities

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her second trimester presents for a routine prenatal ultrasound. What is the primary purpose of this mid-pregnancy ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. To evaluate fetal growth and anatomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • The primary purpose of a mid-pregnancy ultrasound (typically performed between 18-22 weeks) is to evaluate fetal growth and anatomy, including assessing the development of various organs and structures in the fetus. This scan may also be referred to as anomaly scan/ malformation scan/ Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly (TIFFA scan)

 

Educational Objective: Routine ultrasounds done in pregnancy include

 

  1. 1st trimester (6-10 weeks): For confirmation of pregnancy, excluding ectopic pregnancy, number of fetuses, viability, adnexal lesions
  2. 11-14 weeks: Level 1 scan: For Down syndrome screening and uterine artery doppler for preeclampsia screening
  3. 18-22 weeks: TIFFA scan (Targeted imaging for fetal anomaly)
  4. > 28 weeks: Fetal growth and well being, placental localization, amniotic fluid volume, confirming presentation.

 

Reference: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition page 187

choices.text: Penicillin
Prednisone
Valproic acid
Omeprazole

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman is prescribed a medication for her chronic medical condition. She asks if this medication is a teratogen. The physician explains that this medication can potentially cause limb and ear malformations if taken during pregnancy. Which medication is the physician most likely referring to?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Valproic acid

 

Explanation: Valproic acid, an antiepileptic medication, is associated with an increased risk of limb and ear malformations when taken during pregnancy. It is considered a teratogen, and alternative medications should be considered for pregnant women with epilepsy.

 

Other options:

 

Option A, B and D: (penicillin, prednisone, omeprazole) are generally considered safer choices during pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Valproic acid, an antiepileptic medication, is associated with an increased risk of limb and ear malformations when taken during pregnancy.
  • It is considered a teratogen, and alternative medications should be considered for pregnant women with epilepsy.

 

Ref: Page no 240, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Orofacial clefting
Ebstein anomaly
Neurobehavioral abnormalities
Cardiovascular anomalies

questions.text: Lithium in pregnancy is associated with an increased incidence of?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ebstein anomaly

 

Explanation:

 

  • Lithium has been associated with Ebstein anomaly
  • This is an otherwise rare anomaly but has a 3% risk in women on Lithium.
  • Fetal ECHO is indicated in women on Lithium

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Lithium has been associated with Ebstein anomaly
  • This is an otherwise rare anomaly but has a 3% risk in women on Lithium.
  • Fetal ECHO is indicated in women on Lithium

 

Ref: Page no 245, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Adding 9 months and 7 days to the LMP
Adding 38 weeks to the LMP
Adding 280 days to the LMP
Subtracting 3 months and adding 7 days to the LMP

questions.text: All the following methods can be used to calculate the EDD except:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Adding 38 weeks to the LMP

 

Explanation:

 

Calculating the EDD:

 

  • Normal duration of pregnancy: 280 days (40 weeks); hence Option B is incorrect. To arrive at the EDD, we add 280 days or 40 weeks to the LMP.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Calculating the EDD: Naegele’s formula. To the LMP (1st day of the last menstrual day)
    • Add 9 months + 7 days
    • Subtract 3 months and add 7 days
    • For IVF Pregnancies: add 38 weeks to the date of the embryo transfer
  • Remember the EDD falls at 40 weeks (280 days) from the LMP
  • Dating the pregnancy: If discrepancy in dates/ unsure of LMP; the best way to determine the dating is by ULTRASOUND
    • 1st trimester CRL: most accurate (till 14 weeks)
    • BPD in the 2nd trimester

 

Ref: Page no 168, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text: 0.5 kg / week
0.4 kg / week
0.3 kg / week
0.2 kg / week

questions.text: A 25-year Primi gravida is at 24 weeks pregnancy. Her pre-pregnancy BMI was 22. She is concerned she hasn’t been gaining enough weight during pregnancy. What should her ideal weight gain (kg)/ week be?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 0.4 kg/ week

 

Explanation

 

  • In a woman with normal BMI, the ideal weight gain is 0.4kg/ week in the 2nd and 3rd trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ideal weight gain in pregnancy

 

 

Ref: Page no 170, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: High HCG, low ue3, low AFP
Low HCG, high ue3, high AFP
High HCG, high ue3, low AFP
Low HCG, low uE3, high AFP

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida is diagnosed to have Down syndrome of her fetus at 18 weeks. If a triple test was done, what would have been the report?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High HCG, low ue3, low AFP

 

Explanation:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

 

*Easy to remember: B for Big; so in Down’s syndrome; Beta hCG and InhiBin A: Big/ Increased

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Triple and Quadruple test are 2nd trimester biochemical screening tests for Down Syndrome and are done between 15 – 21 weeks.

 

  • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.

 

Page no 284, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Beta HCG and PAPP-A
Unconjugated estradiol and PAPPA
AFP and Inhibin A
AFP and Beta HCG

questions.text: Which of the following is done for screening of Down’s syndrome in the first trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta HCG and PAPP-A

 

Explanation:

 

1st trimester (11-14 weeks) serum analytes for Down’s syndrome screening are: Beta hCG and PAPP-A.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 1st trimester (11-14 weeks) serum analytes for Down’s syndrome screening are: Beta hCG and PAPP-A.
  • This is called the Dual marker/ Double marker

 

Page no 281, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies
Pre-conceptional gene testing of an ova
Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome
Testing of maternal tissue

questions.text: Non-Invasive Prenatal Testing (NIPT) is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Maternal serum for evaluation of Down syndrome

 

Explanation:

 

NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:

  • Introduced in 2011
  • It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were
    • Age ≥ 35 y
    • A positive 1st /2nd trimester analyte-based screening test
    • USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker
    • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
    • Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts.
  • Done after 9 – 10 weeks
  • Results in 7 – 10 days
  • 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome
  • Limitations:
    • Cost
    • The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect:
      • Placental mosaicism
      • Early demise of an aneuploid twin
      • Maternal mosaicism
      • Occult maternal malignancy
      • Limited role in multiple pregnancy
      • In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Amniocentesis for evaluation of fetal chromosomal anomalies: Amniocentesis is a diagnostic method for fetal chromosomal anomalies. It is preferably done after 15 weeks of gestation.
  • Option B. Preconceptional gene testing for an ova: There is no such thing; however preimplantation genetic testing can be done of an embryo in IVF, prior to embryo transfer.
  • Option D. Testing of maternal tissue: This is not a test for screening or diagnosis of Down syndrome

 

Educational Objective:

 

NIPT or cell free DNA screening: Salient features:

  • Introduced in 2011
  • It is a screening test (NOT DIAGNOSTIC)
  • In 2020 (Oct), ACOG guidelines state that along with serum analytes and NT, cell free DNA can be offered to all women as the initial screening modality for Down syndrome. Prior to this the indications were
    • Age ≥ 35 y
    • A positive 1st /2nd trimester analyte-based screening test
    • USG with minor (soft) aneuploidy marker
    • Prior pregnancy with autosomal trisomy
    • Known carriage of a balanced translocation
  • Identification of DNA fragments that are derived primarily from apoptotic trophoblasts.
  • Done after 9 – 10 weeks
  • Results in 7 – 10 days
  • 99% Detection rate for Down syndrome
  • Limitations:
    • Cost
    • The DNA component may not actually reflect fetal DNA and instead may reflect:
      • Placental mosaicism
      • Early demise of an aneuploid twin
      • Maternal mosaicism
      • Occult maternal malignancy
    • Limited role in multiple pregnancy
    • In 4 – 8%: No result due to low fetal fraction of DNA

 

Ref: Page No 284, 285; William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: The risk of a woman carrying a Down syndrome baby is about 1 in 70 at 40 years
Ultrasound features of Down syndrome at 11 – 14 weeks include increased NT and an absent nasal bone
Combined test includes an  NT measurement and the dual marker
Ultrasound at 18 – 20 weeks will miss about 50% of Down syndrome fetuses

questions.text: All are true regarding prenatal Down syndrome screening except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ultrasound at 18 – 20 weeks will miss about 50% of Down syndrome fetuses

 

Explanation:

 

Let’s Discuss all the Options

 

  • Option A. The risk of Down syndrome increases with maternal age. At the age of 40y, the risk os about 1 in 70
  • Option B. At 11-14 weeks, ultrasound features of Down syndrome include
    • An increased nuchal translucency
    • An absent nasal bone
    • Tricuspid regurgitation
    • An abnormal flow in the ductus venosus
  • Option C. Combined test refers to a combination of the NT and Dual marker
  • Option D. An ultrasound at 18-20 weeks will detect upto 70% of Down syndrome babies. Hence this option is correct

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Screening of Down Syndrome:
  • Trisomy 21 (Down syndrome); is the most common non-lethal trisomy
  • Background risk is based on age (At 25 y: 1 in 5000, 30 y: 1 in 1000, 33 y: 1 in 500, 35 y: 1 in 250, 40 y: 1 in 70, 45 y: 1 in 20)
  • Ultrasound at 11 – 14 weeks: Features of Down Syndrome include:
    • Increased NT
    • Absent nasal bone
    • Abnormal flow in the Ductus venosus
    • Tricuspid Regurgitation
  • 1st trimester screening for Down Syndrome includes the Dual marker and the NT.
  • Detection rate for Down Syndrome by a 2nd trimester ultrasound is 70%

 

Ref: Page no 282, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 10 – 13 weeks
10 weeks 6 days – 13 weeks 6 days
12 – 14 weeks
11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days

questions.text: The image below shows the Nuchal translucency (NT) on Ultrasound. A high NT is associated with fetal aneuploidies and poor perinatal outcome. At what gestational period is the NT measured?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days

 

Explanation:

 

Nuchal Translucency (NT):

 

  • Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  • Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  • If NT increased, risk for
    • Fetal aneuploidy
    • Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  • Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Component of first trimester aneuploidy screening
  2. Represents maximum thickness of the subcutaneous translucent area between the skin and soft tissue overlying the fetal spine at the back of the neck.
  3. If NT increased, risk for
    1. Fetal aneuploidy
    2. Various structural anomalies: CVS, hydrops, cystic hygroma
  4. Measured between 11 weeks – 13 weeks 6 days (or 11- 14 weeks)
  5. Criteria to measure the NT
    1. CRL between 45 – 84 mm
    2. Fetus in mid sagittal plane
    3. Fetus in neutral position
    4. Image must be magnified
    5. Widest space should be measured
    6. The amnion must be seen separately
    7. The ‘+’ calipers must be placed on the inner borders of the nuchal space

 

 

  1. NT alone of used: 65% detection rate for Down Syndrome
  2. Combined test: NT + Dual marker (beta hCG + PAPP-A): 80% Detection rate
  3. NT > 3 mm/ > 99th percentile: Significant

 

Ref: Page no 186, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Down Syndrome
Gestational Diabetes
Placenta previa
Preeclampsia

questions.text: A raised uterine pulsatility index at 11-14 weeks on uterine artery doppler is a predictor for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Preeclampsia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Uterine artery blood flow is estimated to rise from 50ml/min early in gestation to 500-700 ml/ min by term
  • Doppler waveform of the uterine artery shows high diastolic flow velocity and markedly turbulent flow.
  • Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of
    • Preeclampsia
    • Gestational HTN
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Thus, option D) Pre-eclampsia is correct.

 

Other Options:

 

  • A raised uterine PI is not related to gestational diabetes, Down syndrome or placenta previa

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Greater resistance to flow (High PI) and diastolic notching  on a uterine artery Doppler at 11-14 weeks are predictors of
    • Preeclampsia
    • Gestational HTN
    • Fetal growth restriction

 

Ref: Page no 214, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening
Nuchal translucency ultrasound
Chorionic villus sampling (CVS)
Amniocentesis

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman is at her second trimester prenatal visit. She inquires about screening for neural tube defects. Which prenatal screening test is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, such as spina bifida, in the second trimester?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening

 

Explanation: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening, typically performed in the second trimester, is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. Elevated levels of AFP in maternal blood may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B: Nuchal Translucency (NT): Done at 11-14 weeks as screening for Down syndrome. It is increased in fetuses with Down syndrome and also increased in other chromosomal abnormalities and congenital abnormalities like cardiac diseases.
  • Option C & Option D: CVS and Amniocentesis are diagnostic techniques for detecting chromosomal abnormalities.

 

Educational Objective: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) screening, typically performed in the second trimester, is used to assess the risk of neural tube defects, including spina bifida. Elevated levels of AFP in maternal blood may indicate the need for further diagnostic tests.

 

Ref: Page no 273, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Palmer sign
Piscacek’s sign
Placental sign
Hegar’s sign

questions.text: A 23-year primigravida presents at 6 weeks with spotting. She is very anxious. On ultrasound, there is a single live intrauterine fetus corresponding to 6 weeks and cardiac activity is seen. She is reassured that this spotting could be normal and due to fusion of the decidua. What is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Placental sign

 

Explanation:

 

Placental sign is mild bleeding/ spotting which may be seen before complete fusion of the decidua vera with the decidua capsularis and is also called implantation bleed; It may be cyclical and may last till 12 weeks.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Palmer sign, Piscacek’s sign and Hegar sign are all clinical signs of pregnancy in the 1st trimester

 

Educational Objective:

 

The named signs in pregnancy are:

 

 

Ref: Page 61; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: 6 – 8 weeks
10 – 12 weeks
14 – 16 weeks
18 – 20 weeks

questions.text: A woman presents to the antenatal OPD. She is not sure of her dates. On abdominal examination, external ballottement is elicited. When is the earliest, this sign can be seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 18-20 weeks

 

Explanation:

 

External Ballotment is as shown below. It appears at 18-20 weeks

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

This is External Ballotment. External Ballottement can be elicited after 18-20 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with one hand abdominally and the other hand receiving the impulse

 

 

  • This is internal Ballottement. It can be elicited at 16 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with the two fingers through the anterior fornix.

 

 

 

Ref: Page 62, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: External Ballotment
Fetal Heart auscultated
Hegar’s Sign
The uterine fundus is palpated at the upper border of the umbilicus

questions.text: A 27-year primigravida visits the antenatal OPD at 24 weeks. An intern examines the patient. Which is NOT an expected finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hegar’s sign

 

  • Hegar’s sign is observed at 6 – 10 weeks. On bimanual examination, the vaginal and abdominal fingers seem to approximate as the upper part of the body of the uterus is enlarged due to the fetus; the lower part of the body is empty and soft and the cervix is comparatively firmer

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: External ballotment appears at 18-20 weeks
  • Fetal heart can be auscultated by 20 weeks
  • The uterine fundus is palpated at the lower border of the umbilicus at 20 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the 2nd trimester, the following are seen:

 

  • On Inspection:
    • Striae gravidarum and linea nigra are seen
  • On Palpation:
    • Uterus palpable at 12 – 14 weeks, lower border of umbilicus at 20 weeks and upper border at 24 weeks
    • External ballotment at 18-20 weeks
    • Internal ballotment after 16 weeks
    • Fetal Heart rate can be auscultated as early as 20 weeks

 

Ref: Page 64, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: a4 b3 c2 d1
a1 b3 c2 d4
a2 b4 c3 d1
a2 b3 c4 d1

questions.text: Match the following change with the period of gestation seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. a2 b3 c4 d1

 

Explanation:

 

  • Internal Ballotment (can be elicited at 16 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with the two fingers through the anterior fornix):  seen between 16 – 28 weeks
  • FHR is 1st auscultated by stethoscope at 18-20 weeks
  • Hegar’s sign (On bimanual exam, the abdominal and vaginal fingers approximate below the body of the uterus) is seen between 8 – 12 weeks
  • Lightening occurs (Feeling of dropping down of the baby in the pelvis) at 38 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Internal Ballotment (can be elicited at 16 weeks by a push to the fetal parts with the two fingers through the anterior fornix):  seen between 16 – 28 weeks
  • FHR is 1st auscultated by stethoscope at 18-20 weeks
  • Hegar’s sign (On bimanual exam, the abdominal and vaginal fingers approximate below the body of the uterus) is seen between 8 – 12 weeks
  • Lightening occurs (Feeling of dropping down of the baby in the pelvis) at 38 weeks

 

Ref:  Page 61; DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics; 9th edition

choices.text: Pelvic grip
Pawlick grip
Fundal grip
Umbilical grip

questions.text: Identify the grip in the picture used for checking ballotability of head?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pawlick grip

 

Explanation

 

  • The image shows the #rd Leopold maneuver; also called the 1st pelvic grip; also called the Pawlik grip.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are 4 Leopold Maneuvers:

 

  1. Fundal grip (A): to assess which fetal pole (cephalic or podalic) occupies the fundus. The breech gives the sensation of a large nodular mass; the head feel hard, round and mobile
  2. The Lateral grip (B): determines the side of the back (hard, resistant) and the limbs (numerous, small irregular mobile parts)
  3. The 1st pelvic grip (3rd maneuver aka Pawlik grip - C): determining fetal presentation.
  4. The 2nd pelvic grip (4th maneuver - D): determines the degree of descent. This maneuver is done facing the feet of the patient and trying to approximate the hands of the examiner. IF the hands approximate; the head has not descended into the pelvis. If the hands diverge, the head has descended into the pelvis.

 

 

Ref: Page 424, William’s Obstetrics; 25th edition

choices.text:
1.  

Bagel sign
Blob sign
Lemon sign
Tubal ring

questions.text: All are ultrasound signs of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Lemon sign

In Suspected unruptured ectopic pregnancy: Trans-vaginal Sonography (TVS) will reveal

    • An absent intra-uterine pregnancy
    • The presence of a pseudo-sac in the uterine cavity
    • The presence of an adnexal mass separate from the ovary
      • Hyperechoic ring surrounding an anechoic sac- seen in 20% (bagel sign/tubal ring sign)
      • Inhomogeneous mass – 60% (blob sign)
      • Obvious gestational sac with a fetal pole – 13%
    • On color doppler: “Ring of fire” seen. (D/d – Corpus luteal cyst)

 

*Lemon sign is seen in a fetus with spina bifida

 

Ref: page no 375, William Obstetrics 25th edition
